Hey Chad, I've been meaning to respond to this message for a while 
but I got distracted my my Ph.D. defense.  Fianly I have enough time.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" <chad@b...> wrote:
> I'm picking apart the Windows NEAT code I have, and mulling over 
some of
> the threads from the group, and I have some questions. 
> 
> innovation #s vs ID #s: are they the same thing? I see some code
> readability to using unique id numbers, but I don't understand what
> innovation #s are for. I was reading postings about remembering 
all the
> innovations. what benifit does this have?
> 

I am not sure about the specific variable names in Windows NEAT (Mat 
Buckland who wrote it would know better), but I can tell you what 
innovation numbers are for.  They are the "historical markings" that 
tell NEAT which gene is which when it matches up different 
topologies.  By keeping an innovation number for each gene that 
represents when it first appeared, it knows when every gene in the 
system first appeared, and can match them up on that basis.  See 
some of my papers on NEAT for the full description of historical 
marking and why it works.

> genotype vs phenotype: I know there has been a lot of talk and 
interest
> in modular structures, where the phenotype is not a direct mapping 
of
> the genotype, but if ( as in with NEAT ) the phenotype IS a direct 
map,
> wouldn't it be simpler not to seperate the two? As I understand 
it, the
> idea is to build networks that can be mutated and crossed with 
other
> networks. What benifit does the genotype/phenotype distinction 
provide?
> 

You could make an argument that both the phenotype and genotype 
could be represented by the same programming structure in a direct 
encoding, but I think keeping them separate is still useful at least 
conceptually since the kinds of operations your perform on them lead 
to different ways of storing data.  For example, genotypes need to 
be crossed over and compared, whereas phenotype neural networks need 
to be activated.  Crossover is well served by a linear sequence of 
genes that desribe the network, whereas activation is best served as 
a connected graph structure where signals can travel down the 
graph.  It is possible a meta-structure can be developed that serves 
both purposes, but unless memory is a huge issue, such a structure 
seems to me more muddled than it's worth in terms of "what it really 
is."  

Also, as a matter of future expansion of the code, trying to fold 
genotype and phenotype into one structure takes away the opportunity 
to introduce even the slightest indirectness.  For example, I later 
introduced "traits" to the genotype, which were actually a list of 
learning rules that different genes could point to.  In other words, 
traits get reused, introducing a slight indirectness to the 
geneotype->phenotype map.  That would not be possible if the 
genotype and phenotype had to be represented in exactly the same way.

> species: can speciation be summarized as method of evolving 
multiple
> populations simultaniously, or is there too much mixing between 
species?
> I havn't read too deep into the speciation code. I don't really 
grasp
> what it's supposed to accomplish. Windows NEAT essentially seems 
to use
> the species class as a simple container with accessors. Is that it?
> 

Speciation is a significant and important component of NEAT.  Their 
main purpose is to protect innovative structures in their own 
niche.  In other words, it allows similar topologies to compete 
mostly among each other instead of directly with the population at 
large.  That way, NEAT is able to test and maintain a good variety 
of increasingly complex topologies.  Another useful aspect of 
speciation is that it prevents completely completely incompatible 
structures from frequently trying to recombine with eachother, since 
that would normally lead to a poor offspring.  However, there is 
some chance such a combination will work well since NEAT keeps track 
of historical markings, so usually I allow some veyr small chance of 
interspecies mating, like 1% or less.  I suggest reading our 
Evolutionary Computation paper which describes the motivation behind 
speciation in detail in the Background section.

ken
